Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this project American Indian students are gaining knowledge and experience by applying cutting-edge metrology techniques using data capturing equipment to improve manufacturing quality. Students are learning equipment operation and maintenance skills and how to analyze and solve complex metrology problems. Students are directly applying the technology in meaningful and relevant projects, thereby growing in competence, comfort, and self-confidence to work successfully as technicians in the high tech manufacturing disciplines. NTU is introducing metrology technology to teachers and students at secondary schools with majority American Indian student populations through workshops and demonstrations to cultivate the STEM pipeline. Investigators are conveying how technologies are used in engineering, manufacturing, architecture and geographic information systems fields and providing learning opportunities for high school students. By developing ties with high tech organizations and educating Navajo students in cutting-edge STEM technology fields, this project is aiming to communicate new education and employment potentials in STEM, which for Navajos living on the reservation was previously considered unattainable.

Navajo Technical University's (NTU) Dimensional Metrology Certification Project is incorporating formal training within various STEM curricula to provide industry standard certifications in advanced metrology technologies, specifically Laser Scanner, Laser Tracker, and Portable Coordinate Measuring Machine. NTU is partnering with industry to develop educational materials and standards leading to certifications and training primarily in the area of Dimensional Metrology data capture and related technical hardware and software operations. NTU students are learning these technologies through culturally relevant metrology technology education materials, problem-based learning methodologies, internships and peer mentoring. The project's evaluation effort will take a mixed-method approach (quantitative and qualitative analysis) to assess and to develop an understanding of what changes in faculty and student learning take place as a result of project activities and the contextual circumstances associated with these changes. In so doing the investigating team will add to the knowledge base of how projects of this type contribute to the improvement of technician education in tribal colleges, thereby offering a model for other similar institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Numerous activities were implemented by Navajo Technical University (NTU) during the past three years to help the ATE Dimensional Metrology Project meet each of its objectives. Positive outcomes were identified through various data collection tools completed by faculty, students and partners, demonstrating the overall success of the project. A high-level summary of project accomplishments and findings is provided below.

 

The ATE Dimensional Metrology Project established new professional certifications in metrology at NTU through purchasing metrology equipment and software, establishing competencies/industry standards for the metrology equipment and software, obtaining training on how to operate the equipment, and providing professional development and training to NTU faculty, lab staff and student interns on the equipment. As a result of these efforts:

  • The NTU Fabrication Lab now has a FARO Laser Scanner, FARO Laser Tracker, and FARO Tracker Arm with Laser Scanner Attachment, as well as related software and additional equipment that expand operational techniques.
  • NTU has competencies/rubrics in place to train students on how to operate the metrology equipment and software following industry standards.
  • NTU faculty obtained a basic understanding of the metrology equipment to help them incorporate hands-on projects into their courses.
  • NTU student interns increased their knowledge, skills, and abilities to operate the metrology equipment, which will help them train other students and assist with course projects in the future. In response to a survey, student interns indicated that their learning experiences increased their knowledge, skills, and/or abilities to operate the ATE equipment.

 

Related to preparing Navajo students to enter the workforce in metrology, the ATE Dimensional Metrology Project provided training to students through demonstrations, projects and workshops, offered student internships, developed industry partnerships, and conducted workshops and lab tours for middle and secondary students. As a result of these efforts:

  • At least 26 NTU students utilized the metrology equipment each year through class projects, individual projects, and/or demonstrations.
  • All 13 of the NTU student interns participated in training workshops related to operating the metrology equipment and students from other tribal colleges and universities were also reached through workshops/demonstrations.
  • NTU made connections with over 20 industry partners to increase project and work opportunities for students, and NTU students participated in internships with at least six different industry partners.
  • At least 100 middle and high school students were introduced to the ATE equipment to help increase their interest in obtaining degrees and careers in the field of metrology.

 

In order to increase job opportunities in metrology for Native American students, the ATE Dimensional Metrology Project developed and participated in internship programs and established employment leads for students. As a result of these efforts:

  • NTU established ongoing, metrology-specific internship programs with three partners who will continue to take NTU interns in the upcoming years.
  • An NTU student was offered a job with one industry partner and two others may be offered positions at another organization.
  • NTU received a new $3.5 million grant to establish an Advanced Manufacturing Center that will include a Certified Metrology and Materials Testing Center. The Center will not only create local internships and jobs, and provide hands-on metrology opportunities for Native American students in advanced manufacturing and metrology, but it will also help the economic development of the Navajo Nation. This is an important, longer-term impact of the ATE Dimensional Metrology Project.

 

Related to establishing NTU as a leader in metrology hardware and software application training, the ATE Dimensional Metrology Project created project documentation, identified opportunities for technology transfer, and obtained support and funding for a new Metrology and Material Testing Center. As a result of these efforts:

  • The PI and interns attended and presented at various conferences.
  • NTU is working with organizations and a university to better utilize and/or incorporate metrology technologies into their efforts.
  • College and industry partners responding to a survey indicated that they gained access to new or different metrology equipment/training as a result of their involvement with NTU metrology activities. They also indicated positive perceptions of NTU as a leader in metrology application training.
  • The Navajo Nation recognized the importance of capitalizing on advanced manufacturing opportunities for economic development and acknowledged that NTU is becoming a leader in advanced technology and additive manufacturing. The President of the Navajo Nation signed a memorandum of agreement with NTU to support the development of the new Advanced Manufacturing Center. The Navajo Nation and Economic Development Agency invested a total of $2.5 million in the building that will house the Metrology and Material Testing Center.

NTU will be continuing to increase technology transfer and establishing themselves as a leader in metrology training through the new Metrology and Material Testing Center. The metrology technologies purchased, as well as the training developed and implemented through the ATE Dimensional Metrology Project, will continue to be utilized in the Education and Services and Construction Branches of the new Certified Center.
